Posts.Content: Hi all I am due to start taxotere on Thursday.  I've had three A/C treatments so far.  I'm interested to hear how people have found taxotere - are the side effects better/worse/different to the AC?   I found the AC side effects followed the same pattern every time for me - a day or two of feelng OK, then a week or so of feeling awful (queasy, even with the expensive meds, weepy, sore all over, icky taste in mouth, very fatigued... ) then gradual improvement with the last week really feeling completely normal.  I've been able to continue running - more slowly, but managed 11km yesterday.   Have people found the taxotere to be quite predictable every treatment cycle? Ann
Posts.Title: Taxotere side effects?

Posts.Content: Thanks Kacang!  I had a secret hope that I would escape the tax side effects altogether, but that didn't happen.  Hoping to feel OK again by day 8 or 9?? Ann
Posts.Title: Taxotere side effects?

Posts.Content: Hi Lucylilly  So glad you escaped the aches and pains! >> I didn't get any of the aches and pains people talk about, I just felt mildly unwell for a few days. My eyebrows and eyelashes fell out >>but I think my head hair started to grow back! Yes, I think my hair started to grow back in the last ten days of my 3rd EC cycle??  I have more fuzz now than I did.  My leg hair is lso regrowing which is annoying!!  But I guess it may all fall out again in a few days  And yes, my eyebrows are thinning by the dayl Ann
Posts.Title: Taxotere side effects?

Posts.Content: Wow, Karen toxophilite!  Well done on your archery achievements! Thanks for sharing your taxotere experience,. I am on day 6 of taxotere today (had my treatment on Thursday.)  Felt absolutely fine on Friday and Saturday (ran 8 km on Friday, did parkrun on Saturday); started to feel achy on Sunday and was in a lot of pain and misery yesterday.  Maybe feeling slightly better this morning but still pretty grotty - it is weird how I hurt basically all over!  Paracetamol doesn't seem to touch it so I took cocodamel last nigh which definitely seemed to help. I think felt worse than I would usually have done yesterday because I couldn't just give in to the tiredness and pain as we had a house guest (bad planning but couldn't be helped...) . The icky mouth is pretty gross I have to say!  Tea tastes of sour milk :(   Ann
Posts.Title: Taxotere side effects?

Posts.Content: Hi - I was told to take the Emend three hours before the chemo.  :) Good luck! Ann
Posts.Title: Daft question: anti-emetics

Posts.Content: Kacang One piece of advice I was given, which I mostly followed, was not to eat my favourite food as it could put me off it forever. The only ones I tried were baked beans and mashed potatoes, both of which I love, but they did taste gross so I didn't go there again.  Couldn't agree with this more!!!  Several foods are dead to me forever because I ate them in my sickest phase.  I would also add, don't use perfumes  / shower gels etc that are scented when you are feeling nauseous as you may dislike the scent afterwards.  Bodyshop British Rose showergel makes me feel nauseous now when I smell it! Ann
Posts.Title: Taste

Posts.Content: Hi volvox167  I am so sorry you are going through all the stress of breast cancer, plus worrying about how it may affect your fitness and your life in future.  All the more so since you must be a pretty impressive rower to be training for a national competition!! When I was diagnosed in March this year, I was training for the Paris marathon.  I ran it the week before my surgery - which was good because it gave me something nice to think about when I went under with the anaesthetic.  LIke you, I worried - still do worry - about getting my fitness back.  I ran through chemo (which I finished at the end of September) and I'm running through radiotherapy (which I will finish next week.)  It has been hard and being slower than I used to be has been upsetting, even though I know it's obviously to be expected.  But I am have kept going and as I move further out from the chemo I can feel myself getting stronger.  My other hobby is rock climbing; that is where most of my anxiety about regaining my fitness is, because (as with rowing) it relies a lot on arm/chest/back muscles, and I can still feel the effects of the lymph node clearance 6 months later...  BUT - although I am anxious about it in my heart of hearts I do believe I will eventually get back to my old self, fitness wise.  And so will you. When is your surgery?  Best of luck, will be thinking of you - Ann xx
Posts.Title: Will I ever get my fitness back? Will it be easier if i don't have...

Posts.Content: Totally agree :)  My watch does a little fireworks display when I hit my step goal.  And there's notbing like the pain when you  realise you walked somewhere and left your watch/fitbit behind!!   Ann
Posts.Title: Still worried about future

Posts.Content: Totally agree :)  My watch does a little fireworks display when I hit my step goal.  And there's notbing like the pain when you  realise you walked somewhere and left your watch/fitbit behind!!   Ann
Posts.Title: Still worried about future

Posts.Content: Hi simba4me - I felt very weak and ill for a good two weeks after my surgeries.  The node clearance particularly takes a while to recover from. I was unlucky; I had to have a second operation following my lumpectomy; hopefully they will have got clear margins for you and you will avoid that.   Hopefully your drain will come out very soon; I felt a lot better once I'd got rid of mine, it made me feel sick looking at it! Ann
Posts.Title: Still worried about future

Posts.Content: Hi simba4me - I felt very weak and ill for a good two weeks after my surgeries.  The node clearance particularly takes a while to recover from. I was unlucky; I had to have a second operation following my lumpectomy; hopefully they will have got clear margins for you and you will avoid that.   Hopefully your drain will come out very soon; I felt a lot better once I'd got rid of mine, it made me feel sick looking at it! Posts.Title: Still worried about future

Posts.Content: Thanks Lin!  Wonderful to hear that you are enjoying life to the full.  I have my return to work interview at the end of next week - I am quite anxious about going back to work but also lookjng forward to it.  I think they will do a phased return... I hope so as I'm sure I will find it exhausting. (I am a teacher -head of department in a 6th form college).  I agree about the fitbit - I used to love mine, but switched to a Garmin running watch that also had a step counter just as I was diagnosed.  Even though I had a fair amount of time after each chemo session where I was out of action, my average step count from March when I was diagnosed till now has remained above 10k a day :)  Ann

I hope so as I'm sure I will find it exhausting. Posts.Content: I hope it goes well on Tuesday!   My operation seems like a long time ago - the first one was in April, the second in May.  I finished chemo at the end of September, and will finish radiotherapy on Monday!  Ann

Posts.Content: I hope it goes well on Tuesday!   My operation seems like a long time ago - the first one was in April, the second in May.  I finished chemo at the end of September, and will finish radiotherapy on Monday!  Ann

Posts.Content: Hi Gill We started chemo at about the same time - good luck with the radiotherapy! I finished mine on November 20. :) Ann
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ December Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Sorry, that should say at "three" week intervals - I'm using my phone... A xx
Posts.Title: Lots of questions!

Posts.Content: OMG  autocorrect gone mad! "Vengeful" was supposed to be "celebration. And "sure to start" was supposed to be "due to start". Sorry I sound so incoherent!
Posts.Title: Lots of questions!

Posts.Content: Hi Emma I had a similar diagnosis to yours. I was given EC/T chemo - so 6 cycles of chemo at the week internals, three cycles of Epirubicin and Cyclophosphamide, and three of Taxotere. My hair started to fall out on day 17 of my first cycle, so my husband shaved it for me just before my second cycle. I was really dreading losing my hair but it wasn't bad in the end. We made it into a vengeful of sorts - got some champagne :) I have just finished chemo, sure to start radiotherapy on the 23rd. Best of luck Ann xx
Posts.Title: Lots of questions!

Posts.Content: In the hospital where I had my surgery, yes - you wear your knickers, one of their gowns, and your dressing gown over the top. I walked to the room where they do the anaesthetic and took off the dressing gown there.  Stayed covered up with the gown till I was unconscious :)  I woke up in a binder (had lumpectomy) which was slightly weird to think of them moving me around while I was unconscious -but they are used to it, they do it several tiimes every single day.   For my first surgery, I didn't bring a dressing gown, so I used two of their gowns, one facing each way.  Unfortunatley I had to have a second surgery but the upside of that was that I knew to bring my dressing gown :) A x
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: In the hospital where I had my surgery, yes - you wear your knickers, one of their gowns, and your dressing gown over the top. I walked to the room where they do the anaesthetic and took off the dressing gown there.  Stayed covered up with the gown till I was unconscious :)  I woke up in a binder (had lumpectomy) which was slightly weird to think of them moving me around while I was unconscious -but they are used to it, they do it several tiimes every single day.   For my first surgery, I didn't bring a dressing gown, so I used two of their gowns, one facing each way.  Unfortunatley I had to have a second surgery but the upside of that was that I knew to bring my dressing gown :) A x
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: Thanks Snowys Mum  I think I probably just need to lower my expectations and give myself a bit of a break ... it is reassuring to hear that other people got tired too. Ann
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy fatigue?

Posts.Content: I think you are right toxophilite, I realised today that I have been so focused on getting through the treatment that I really haven't got to grips with having been diagnosed with cancer in the first place.... I saw the doctor at the occupational health place today and he recommended a phased return to work, and that I have some CBT as well to help me manage all the anxiety and fear that I've been denying...  Ann
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy fatigue?

Posts.Content: I had my last radiotherapy on Monday (20 sessions of radiotherapy, followjng on from surgery and chemo) and I am all of  a sudden absolutely exhausted!  I didn't get particularly tired during the radiotherapy itself.  In fact I was excited because I could feel my body returning to normal - my muscles felt stronger and I was able to run a bit faster.  So I  thought I would probably escape any radiotherapy fatigue, especally because I am lucky enough to live very close to the radiotherapy centre, so I didn't have the  long commute that many do. But this week I feel absolutely shattered, and it's so annoying, as I was hoping to have a week or two where I felt normal before returning to work ... I have my return to work interview with the occupational health people tomorrow (I'm a teacher)...  So is this normal?  Has anyone else suddenly been hit with fatigue after finished radio? Ann
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy fatigue?

Posts.Content: Ha ha, I noticed the not-looking yesterday! We should all become shop-lifters! Ann
Posts.Title: No headscarf

Posts.Content: Hi all Thanks to this thread I ran a 10k race yesterday without a head covering. I felt a little self conscious but it was much less awkward than I'd thought it would be . :) (Though I had my having with me which helped...) Ann
Posts.Title: No headscarf

Posts.Content: Thank you! Don't think I would have been brave enough without the posts here! Yes, that's my daughter :) Ann
Posts.Title: No headscarf

Posts.Content: Hi Minnie84 -  Yes, it is strange how they suggest different things!  I was concerned that I wasn't getting the Zoladex - was worried I was missing out on something beneficial - but she was adamant I wasn't - and yet your oncologist has said the opposite.  Very strange.  I have  my signing off appointment in six weeks or so, so probably not till the new year and am also going to make a list of questions to ask.   I haven't found the Tamoxifen too bad so far.  (Ten days in).  I have the same number of hot flashes that I had on chemo so no worse, and I don't have joint pain etc (or not yet anyway).  I have been quite weepy today but that may be unrelated to the tamoxifen - had my return to work interview; the doctor asked how I was coping with the actual diagnosis of cancer as opposed to the treatment and I just dissolved into tears.  I think this is almost the first time that it actually hit me that yes, I had cancer.  (I found it stressful even typing that!) Ann
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hi Minnie84 -  Yes, it is strange how they suggest different things!  I was concerned that I wasn't getting the Zoladex - was worried I was missing out on something beneficial - but she was adamant I wasn't - and yet your oncologist has said the opposite.  Very strange.  I have  my signing off appointment in six weeks or so, so probably not till the new year and am also going to make a list of questions to ask.   I haven't found the Tamoxifen too bad so far.  (Ten days in).  I have the same number of hot flashes that I had on chemo so no worse, and I don't have joint pain etc (or not yet anyway).  I have been quite weepy today but that may be unrelated to the tamoxifen - had my return to work interview; the doctor asked how I was coping with the actual diagnosis of cancer as opposed to the treatment and I just dissolved into tears.  I think this is almost the first time that it actually hit me that yes, I had cancer.  (I found it stressful even typing that!) Ann
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hi Minnie84  It does seem very confusing!  I have just started tamoxifen (having just finished chemo and radiotherapy).  I asked my oncologist why some people were prescribed zoladex as well as tamoxifen and she said that there was sone research which looked at using both but that using both zoladex and tamoxifen  didn't show any benefit when compared to tamoxifen alone.  (I am 47 and hadn't had  any menopausal symptoms pre-chemo).  It may be different for much younger women though? Can you phone your oncologist's secretary and leave a message to say that you would like to discuss the zoladex?   I haven't had my "signing off" appointment with my oncologist yet, but can imagine that it will feel a bit frightening to be on my own between the yearly checkups... Ann
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hi Minnie84  It does seem very confusing!  I have just started tamoxifen (having just finished chemo and radiotherapy).  I asked my oncologist why some people were prescribed zoladex as well as tamoxifen and she said that there was sone research which looked at using both but that using both zoladex and tamoxifen  didn't show any benefit when compared to tamoxifen alone.  (I am 47 and hadn't had  any menopausal symptoms pre-chemo).  It may be different for much younger women though? Can you phone your oncologist's secretary and leave a message to say that you would like to discuss the zoladex?   I haven't had my "signing off" appointment with my oncologist yet, but can imagine that it will feel a bit frightening to be on my own between the yearly checkups... Ann
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hi all So I started Tamoxifen yesterday ... first day of (fingers crossed) the next ten years!   I asked the oncologist how we would know if the Tamoxifen was having an effect, and she basically said we wouldn't know for sure - but when I googled it when I got home, I found some references to some people metabolising it better than others, and hence some people not getting much benefit from it.  Is this not tested for?  Did they decide it wasn't a big deal?  The articles I found seem to be from a couple of years ago. Ann
Posts.Title: How to see if Tamoxifen is working?

Posts.Content: Hi sunriser52  I can really relate to your worries; I too am very scared that my cancer will recur.  (I was diagnosed in March, had lumpectomy (*2) and chemo, and will finish radiotherapy on Monday).   I think the reason why MRIs aren't standard is that, firstly, we have been treated for cancer so we should have a good chance of being cancer free at the end of it.  And secondly, they would produce a lot of false positives, which are very worrying to deal with.  I had a chest x ray and CT scan at the start of my treatment because I had some shoulder/back pain.  The CT scan showed two areas in my ribs which the radiologist thought might be from metastases; my oncologist thought probably not - so I had to wait six months and have a repeat scan.  During those six months I was constantly trying to worry about the second scan; and my anxiety after scan 2 while waiting for the results was almost unbearable.  Luckily for me, the radiologist thought the second scan was consistent with healing fractures rather than cancer - it does make sense because I had whooping cough last year and hurt my ribs due to the extreme coughing.  So my point is, I had a lot of anxiety caused by a false positive - an MRI wouldn't necessarily put your mind at rest, as you might have to wait for follow up scans if they see "iffy" areas anywhere - it wouldn't necessarily be a cut and dried answer. So I can totally understand your anxiety - I am suffering from it too, particularly as my mum had breast cancer which recurred 6 years after treatment and was not curable at that stage  - but I just am not sure that an MRI scan would really help lay it to rest... Ann
Posts.Title: MRI scan after main treatment

Posts.Content: Just thought I would say I had my treatment at East Surrey, so also in your neck of the woods - wishing you the best of luck with your treatment! Ann
Posts.Title: Jumped to breast cancer secondary forum and had no responses to my...

Posts.Content: KerryCake Love that you ran from the hospital!!  Amazing!! A xx
Posts.Title: Any runners here?

Posts.Content: Hi all I am due to start chemo on Wednesday (had WLE and sentinal node biopsy on April 18th, then second surgery and axillary node clearance on May 10th, as the first surgery showed one positive lymph node and didn't get clear margins).  I will be having EC.  Wondering if anyone has managed to keep up some running during chemo?  I started running (slowly!) again last week, which was  3 weeks after my surgery - wondering if I'll be able to keep up any fitness during chemo? Ann x
Posts.Title: Any runners here?

Posts.Content: Thanks ronstar - will try to remember to listen to my body - great advice!  It sounds like it's a fine line between pushing yourself enough to get out there, but not so much that it affects your recovery. A xx
Posts.Title: Any runners here?

Posts.Content: ArgyMargy thanks for the recommendation for the thread bout running on treatment!! I hope the doxetaxel goes well for you A xx
Posts.Title: Any runners here?

Posts.Content: Hi optimum  so good to hear about your experiences!  And great to hear that you are managing to keep exercising - very encouraging!! A xx
Posts.Title: Any runners here?

Posts.Content: Hi KarenJ62  good luck for the half marathon!  Wonderful that you are back in shape for it!  I ran the Paris marathon 10 days before my first surgery which was on April 18; had to have a second surgery three weeks later, and will be starting chemo tomorrow ... I have been running (slower than usual - my arm still hurts a bit from the lymph node removal) for the last couple of weeks, but already I notice that, even though I weigh less (hard to eat when anxious) I've lost muscle tone ... Am definitely going to go for a symbolic pre-chemo run tomorrow morning, and thereafter will have to see how I go.  Really hoping to run at least a few times during each 3 week cycle -
Posts.Title: Any runners here?

Posts.Content: Hi Sazzab it sounds like we have a lot in common!  I'm 47, and  ran the Paris marathon in April this year a couple of weeks after my diagnosis and 10 days before my first surgery :)  And I'm also a teacher, though  I think my work will do a phased return for me during radiation.  It sounds like I will have to scale back my expectations; doesn't sound like running very much will be realistic.  It really keeps me sane, so I will try to do as much as I can - but may have to resign myself to walking instead.  Going to go for a symbolic run the morning of my first chemo, though :)
Posts.Title: Any runners here?

Posts.Content: Thanks  Crystaljuju, it's so good to hear about others' experiences on this new journey.  Sounds like running is probably not going to be much of an option - oh well, it is what it is.  I will try and see how it goes.  I did laugh when my oncologist said I could run so long as I wasn't tired - I know he meant excessively, unusually tired, but even when healthy I've never been on a run where I haven't been tired and really wanted to stop, so it might be hard to know if I should push myself or stop.  Will just have to take it one day at a time -  A xx

A xx
Posts.Title: Any runners here?

Posts.Content: Thanks FC59!  Gosh, 4 classes a week, that's impressive!!  Thanks for the inspiration and the advice about listening to your body - A xx

Posts.Content: toxophilite congrats on the archery achievements!  Must feel great to be back in the game! A xx
Posts.Title: Any runners here?

Posts.Content: Hi Nikki, yes, I had some bleeding after my second cycle of EC. It cleared up on its own. The oncologist said it's pretty common, her words were that the drugs cause "increased vascularity" so any blood vessels are more delicate. Ann xx
Posts.Title: * * * SEPTEMBER BREAST CANCER CHEMO CLUB * * *

Posts.Content: I finished chemo on September 28 and am happy that my hair is starting to return.  It started to grow back while I was on the taxotere, and I have now progressed - and these are the categories that my kids used to describe my hair status - through kiwifruit, then coconut, and now to baby monkey.  But my eyebrows are still basically non-existent, and my eyelashes are very short and sparse (which is annoying because pre-chemo my eyelashes were one of the things that I actually liked about my body!)  Anyway, so I'm drawing eyebrows on every morning; it looks OK-ish except for the times when it goes wrong and I look like a drag queen or a creepy clown.  Also it's such a faff; I never bothered with eye makeup before all this. Thinking of asking for microblading for my Chrismas present - has anyone had this done and if so are you happy with the results? Ann
Posts.Title: Microblading eyebrows post-chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Deb09 - I know just how you feel, I have felt exactly the same way myself - I had back/shoulder pain which turned out to be nothing sinister - but before I knew that, the stress and worry made me focus on it and increased the pain greatly.  I was sure the cancer had spread - but it hadn't.  Lots of love Ann
Posts.Title: Stressed/Anxious

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the feedback everyone!  One of the hairdressers in the high street where I live is advertising microblading currently so I might pop in and see what they think.  I never thought I'd miss my eyebrows so much! Ann
Posts.Title: Microblading eyebrows post-chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi I have also just started tamoxifen - today will be day 3 for me.  So far, I haven't had any  new side effects - just the same horrid hot flashes and night sweats that started during chemo.  My oncologist said to me that if I were to get bad side effects, they can prescribe venlaflexine - it is an antidepressant but it reduces the hot flashes by up to 60% and also helps with the other side effects of tamoxifen.  Maybe you could ask your doctor what they think about it? Ann
Posts.Title: tamoxifen problems

Posts.Content: Shoes on or off for radiotherapy?  What do you all do?  I asked the nurse yesterday if they had any preferences and she looked at me as if I was crazy and said whatever I liked.  But it feels odd either way!   And question number 2: does the radiotherapy equipment work best at certain temperatures?  I had my first session yesterday and it was absolutely freezing in there. Ann
Posts.Title: Silly radiotherapy question -

Posts.Content: Hi Ella I found my lump in March this year.  Same as you, I told my close family and close friends immediately, as well the work colleagues in my department (who are my friends anyway) and personnel at work.  I didn't tell other people  for a while, though. There was a month during which we seemed to be endlessly waiting - for biopsy results, for meetings with the surgeon, for a treatment plan, for a surgery date - and for some reason I didn't want to make it properly public till all that was nailed down.  I did start to feel awkward about it though, as my life on facebook seemed exactly as it usually is - eg I ran the Paris marathon the week before the  surgery - but at the same time, my life wasn't normal at all anymore. It started to feel dishonest to keep it secret any longer.  So after much angst about how much to say and how to say it -  which really stressed me, I wanted to get it out there but also didn't want to, as it made it all seem to real- eventually my husband put it on facebook for me at Easter. This what he said -"Four weeks ago Annalise as diagnosed with breast cancer. On Tuesday she will have surgery followed by further therapy. We have managed to squeeze in some really good times ahead of this but she is so strong, fit and loved that we are sure she will be running, climbing and back at work soon." As for it being TMI, I decided that facebook was a good way for me to connect with those of my friends and family who are far away,  and that I should feel free to share as much or as little as I wanted to.  I did unfriend some people at that point in time because I realised that I didn't really "know" them anymore - eg people from the distant past or vague acquaintances who I had no real connection with. Hope this helps, Good luck Ann
Posts.Title: How to tell friends?

Posts.Content: I know what you mean about feeling very alone and exposed.  I felt that way on day 1; days 2 and 3 have been better.  And, the temperature was normal on days 2 and 3; they said that they can't control the airconditioning in there, it is centrally controlled, so some days it is just absolutely freezing and other days it's fine. Ann
Posts.Title: Silly radiotherapy question -

Posts.Content: I used it - didn't have any problems :) Ann xx
Posts.Title: Can you use fake tan on head while on chemo? :0)

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about the mputh ulcers, that sounds horrible :(  I have my second EC today - think I originally started a week after you - hoping it goes OK.  The first cycle wasn't too bad - grotty bit in the middle, but first few days and last 10 days fine - A xx
Posts.Title: *** July 2017 Chemo Club ***
